2050, it will be vital to mobilize sufficient capital to drive decarbonization in developing countries."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-12-06T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAs climate change\u003c/strong\u003e indicators continue to break records and global temperatures and extreme weather events advance, the urgency to act to ensure a sustainable future is mounting.[[footnote 1]] Achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement will require fundamental changes in energy and land-use systems worldwide, and developing countries are a key part of this transformation.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003ePoised as they are for significant economic and population expansion, without support for decarbonization and green growth developing countries will likely increase their share of emissions over the coming decades. However, the climate conversation around these countries can often be focused on adaptation and resilience to withstand changes from climate change, rather than the decarbonization efforts that could mitigate its worst effects and position these economies for green growth. This could undermine global progress toward net zero and, ultimately, erode economic prosperity in developing nations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this article, we explore how economic growth, inclusion, and climate action are intimately connected and estimate the climate financing gap that needs to be bridged to ensure adequate financing of climate imperatives in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. Nine levers are highlighted that could help attract the private and public funding required to unlock investments to build a safer and more prosperous future, not just in these regions but for the world more broadly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eDeveloping countries have a critical role to play in the global transition to net zero\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the next decade, the economies and populations in developing countries are projected to be among the fastest growing in the world. Between now and 2050, half of additions to the global population will likely be in Africa and about 30 percent in Asia.[[footnote 3]] \u003cspan\u003eFurthermore, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates that, compared to 2021, developing countries\u0026rsquo; GDP could increase by 40 percent to more than $60 trillion by 2028, a per-capita increase of over 30 percent\u003c/span\u003e.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, climate change could limit or even derail this progress. Average temperatures have risen by about 1.2\u0026deg;C since the pre-industrial era and, globally, temperature and precipitation extremes are already 4.8 and 1.3 times more likely to occur, respectively.[[footnote 5]] Developing countries are the most vulnerable to these impacts (Exhibit 1). In August 2022, for example, Pakistan experienced severe flooding that covered a third of the country, resulting in around 15,000 casualties and displacing 8 million people.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAfrica is considered the most climate-vulnerable region in the world owing to a high dependence on ecosystem goods (such as clean air, water, and fertile soil) for livelihoods, underdeveloped agricultural systems, limited infrastructure, a lack of social safety nets, and lower adaptive capacity (linked to weaker economies, institutions, and governance structures).[[footnote 7]] In 2022, Niger and Nigeria faced one of the deadliest floods in recent history, damaging 300,000 homes, inundating half-a-million hectares of land, and resulting in more than 800 fatalities.[[footnote 8]] In the Horn of Africa in the east of the continent, an acute drought has affected over 20 million people and led to the loss of over 2 million livestock in Kenya alone.[[footnote 9]] Projections indicate further increases in such climate-related incidents, likely leading to a broad range of social and economic impacts.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a result of these risks, the climate conversation around developing countries, especially in Africa, can often be focused on adaptation and resilience rather than decarbonization. However, taking decisive decarbonization action in these countries would be needed to support the world\u0026rsquo;s transition to net zero and thus be vital to ensure that they avert the worst climate change impacts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDeveloping countries already account for a sizable share of emissions and, given future population and GDP growth projections, this is set to rise. While the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries have made some progress, reducing their emissions by 8 percent between 2010 and 2019, the rest of the world saw a 22 percent increase in emissions during this time.[[footnote 11]] At around 10 percent of the global total (when land-use emissions and all greenhouse gases are considered), Africa already accounts for more greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions than Europe; however, per capita emissions are still higher in Europe.[[footnote 12]] Indeed, as recent modeling work has shown, in a scenario where industrialized countries achieve a 1.5\u0026deg;C-consistent emissions trajectory but Africa, India, and Southeast Asia follow a \u0026ldquo;current policies\u0026rdquo; trajectory, global GHG emissions would remain substantial by 2050, leading to an increase in global average temperatures by 2100 of 2 to 2.3\u0026deg;C. This would miss the Paris Agreement goals and lead to substantially higher risks of triggering self-reinforcing warming feedback loops in the Earth\u0026rsquo;s system.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn short, it is likely only possible to limit warming and achieve the Paris Agreement goals if developing countries achieve a green growth, low-carbon development pathway. Moreover, such a pathway also holds significant potential to deliver new economic opportunities to developing countries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSetting a course for green growth\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe stage is set for significant green growth in developing countries. Climate investments by industrialized countries have dramatically reduced the cost of many clean technologies\u0026mdash;a trend that is likely to continue\u0026mdash;making renewable energy the lowest-cost power source in large parts of the world.[[footnote 14]] Many other clean technologies are also rapidly approaching tipping points where their costs are becoming lower than those of high-emission incumbent options. Choosing low-carbon technologies will soon be the economically rational choice across large parts of the global economy, further lowering costs and increasing productivity. In many cases, clean technologies also have significant co-benefits such as cutting air pollution, improving sanitation, increasing energy access, and more.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDeveloping countries have a significant opportunity to leverage these technologies to build low-carbon development pathways. McKinsey research has previously highlighted ten high-potential green growth opportunities for Africa centered around four key pillars\u0026mdash;energy access and affordability, inclusive green growth, health and quality of life, and green exports\u0026mdash;that could create jobs and bring new export revenue to the continent (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, thanks to its abundant renewable resources, Namibia is advantageously positioned to produce and export green hydrogen, a vital resource for decarbonization, especially in hard-to-abate sectors.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGlobal hydrogen demand is expected to increase from 140 megatons per annum (Mtpa) of hydrogen equivalent in 2030 to 660 Mtpa in 2050, owing to its versatility and unique ability to connect power, gas, chemicals, and fuel markets.[[footnote 16]] Namibia aspires to create an at-scale green hydrogen industry with a production target of 10 to 12 Mtpa hydrogen equivalent by 2050 for export to Asia and Europe. Capturing this opportunity could boost GDP by up to $6 billion by 2040\u0026mdash;an increase of 50 percent on today\u0026rsquo;s GDP\u0026mdash;and create up to 600,000 jobs by 2040.[[footnote 17]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIndeed, as the Namibian example shows, the role of developing countries in the world\u0026rsquo;s energy transition can extend well beyond decarbonizing their economies. For instance, many countries in Africa, Asia, and Latin America are rich in the mineral resources essential for clean energy technologies and renewable resources that could enable the production of sustainable and clean energy, reducing environmental impact, and fostering long-term energy security (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The role of developing countries in the net-zero transition extends beyond their domestic emissions\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\u003ch2\u003eBridging the climate finance gap in developing countries\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDelivering on the potential for decarbonization and green growth in developing countries will require a significant increase in climate-focused investment. Based on capital deployed in 2019, our research indicates that about $2 trillion in additional finance is needed per annum by 2030 to meet the Paris Agreement goals and cap warming at 1.5\u0026deg;C above pre-industrial levels (Exhibit 3). This amount includes investments needed to transform the energy system, respond to growing climate change vulnerability, scale sustainable agriculture, and restore natural capital and biodiversity. An additional $3 trillion per annum is also required to invest in the human capital and broader infrastructure needed to meet the development goals of developing countries.[[footnote 18]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 3]]\n[[sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo secure this funding, various domestic and international sources of climate finance would need to be explored\u0026mdash;including new sources of concessional capital (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Sources of climate finance\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs of 2019, about $450 billion of climate finance was deployed annually in developing countries, roughly 20 percent of what is needed by 2030.[[footnote 19]] Around 60 percent of this capital was directed at the energy transition, with the remaining 30 percent allocated to agriculture, food, and land use, and 10 percent to nature, adaptation, and resilience.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eResearch indicates that, of the additional $2 trillion needed for climate financing in developing countries, about $830 billion (approximately 40 percent) could come from domestic resource mobilization (DRM), based on a weighted average of the percentage of domestic capital compared to external capital sources across all sectors of the economy (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Uncertainties and additional complexities\u0026rdquo;).[[footnote 21]] This amount equates to a 15 percent increase in total DRM from 2019. Of this, about 40 percent is likely to come from \u0026ldquo;business as usual\u0026rdquo; GDP growth, but the bulk would require additional capital mobilization measures from public and private sources.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe remaining 60 percent of the financing gap (about $1.1 trillion per annum) would need to be filled externally from international capital sources\u0026mdash;both private and public, as not all climate investment needs are suitable for private capital\u003c/span\u003e.[[footnote 22]] Mitigation efforts typically have a business case that can attract private capital on a stand-alone basis, or public sector actors that are able to derisk the investments sufficiently to crowd in private capital through the use of instruments such as debt guarantees or first-loss capital investments. By contrast, adaptation is likely to require predominantly public or concessional funding. This gap could be filled partially by achieving higher leverage ratios (private sector investment mobilized for each dollar of concessional finance) on existing international concessional climate finance. However, significantly more concessional finance would also be required.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAdditional domestic capital mobilization measures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the longer term, capital mobilization from sovereign (public) sources could be accelerated by growing the tax base through accelerated economic growth\u0026mdash;for example, by implementing green growth strategies. But in the near term, enhanced tax collection could play a key role. On average, lower- and middle-income countries collect only 15 to 20 percent of GDP in tax revenue versus more than 30 percent for upper-income countries.[[footnote 23]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdditionally, eliminating fossil fuel subsidies in some countries as well as decreasing debt burdens and borrowing costs could free up public funds. In 2021, African countries dedicated 14 percent of income from exports of goods and services, primary income, and workers' remittances to external debt servicing.[[footnote 24]] Automatic interest moratoriums in the event of catastrophes, sovereign debt restructuring, including measures such as debt-for-climate swaps, and reducing borrowing costs through measures to reduce country risk and increase sovereign bond liquidity through better-developed repo markets could be critical to lower the interest burden and free up the necessary capital. However, it is important to bear in mind that an increase in sovereign capital mobilization may be slowed down by headwinds caused by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, supply impacts from the conflict in Ukraine, rising interest rates, and debt distress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo mobilize additional domestic capital from private sources, measures that incentivize local finance deployment would likely need to be developed. This could include deepening local financial sectors through improved regulation and oversight, risk assessment frameworks, or capability building.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRaising more international climate finance\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are two primary ways to increase the amount of international climate finance: a more effective use of existing concessional finance to mobilize more private investment and increasing the amount of concessional finance. Both would be needed to close the climate finance gap in developing countries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCrowding in more private investors would require a more effective deployment of public capital to drive higher leverage ratios on concessional capital. Currently, leverage ratios of blended finance arrangements of development finance institutions (DFIs) and multilateral development banks (MDBs) are often less than one.[[footnote 25]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey estimates an achievable leverage ratio of about 1.6, that is, about $1.6 of private capital mobilized for every $1.0 of public or concessional finance.[[footnote 26]] Using this ratio and considering a low private sector participation in adaptation-related investments, the financing gap remaining after realizing the potential for increased domestic resource mobilization could be closed with an additional $600 billion per annum of public concessional finance, including multilateral and bilateral financing, and about $500 billion per annum from private international capital.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBased on this analysis, it is clear that significant additional concessional climate finance is required. Several proposals are already being discussed to increase public concessional climate finance through MDB and DFI reforms. For example, the Bridgetown Agenda looks at how existing MDB and DFI balance sheets could mobilize more capital deployment through changes to capital adequacy requirements or the reallocation of special drawing rights.[[footnote 27]] The Blended Finance Taskforce estimates that proposed reforms to MDBs and DFIs could mobilize about $120 billion of additional concessional finance per annum, which, in turn, could crowd in approximately $190 billion in additional private finance.[[footnote 28]] This could close 20 to 30 percent of the climate finance gap after potential increases in domestic resource mobilization are accounted for.[[footnote 29]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis leaves an estimated remaining gap of about $480 billion per annum in additional concessional (external public) finance required by 2030. This number is substantial, equivalent to more than double the total (not only climate-related) 2022 disbursements of the top five DFIs or the total official development assistance received from OECD countries in 2022.[[footnote 30]] It implies more than quadrupling the currently committed $100 billion per annum North\u0026ndash;South concessional climate finance, or tripling official development assistance to just over 1 percent of OECD countries\u0026rsquo; 2022 gross national income, up from currently 0.36 percent.[[footnote 31]] Moreover, this amount would only cover the estimated climate finance gap and does not account for additional development finance needs for non-climate investment into human capital, health, or infrastructure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eNine key levers to catalyze funding for developing countries\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo spur investment in developing countries, we highlight nine key levers that could be deployed across three dimensions: increasing external concessional capital, enabling more private foreign direct investment (FDI), and increasing sovereign and private domestic resource mobilization. This is by no means an exhaustive list but rather represents priority actions with the highest impact and probability of success in increasing the amount of climate finance flowing toward these regions (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch3\u003eIncreasing external concessional capital\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIncreasing external concessional capital can be achieved, first, through increasing capital deployment from existing institutions\u0026rsquo; capitalization. The Bridgetown Agenda, for example, proposes leveraging unused IMF Special Drawing Rights as collateral to lend to climate projects in developing countries and to adjust capital adequacy requirements to mobilize more capital through existing MDB balance sheets. Second, new international concessional climate finance could be raised through new instruments like the Loss and Damage Fund agreed at COP27, as well as through new levies that have been proposed such as global climate taxes and levies.[[footnote 32]] Third, additional capital could be sourced by shifting more philanthropic funding towards climate, specifically in developing countries. Philanthropy is unique as it is flexible and has fewer constraints than other sources of capital but currently it plays a minor role. A 2018 Harvard Kennedy School report found that only 1 to 2 percent of the $875 billion philanthropic capital deployed was directed to climate change, though this share has likely risen since.[[footnote 33]] In previous research, McKinsey has laid out the potential for philanthropy to drive catalytic investments, take risks, and innovate in climate finance.[[footnote 34]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEnabling more private foreign direct investment\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[sidebar 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo enable more private foreign direct investment (FDI), countries could first expand the deployment of finance instruments with higher leverage ratios in the climate space, for instance, insurance, guarantees, blended finance structures, or currency hedging. Second, they could implement actions that improve country risk and the investment environment, for example, through structural domestic reform to improve public-private partnership (PPP) law, removing red tape, tackling corruption, and lifting capital controls. A third lever could be to scale carbon market ecosystems and enabling environments. This could include scaling project development and validation capacity on the supply side and securing advance market commitments on the demand side. These levers are unpacked in greater detail in sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Delivering on priority actions to drive private foreign direct investment.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIncreasing sovereign and private domestic resource mobilization\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSovereign and private domestic resource mobilization could be increased, one, by deepening capabilities in local financial sectors to improve the management and implementation of climate-related regulation and the use of finance instruments specific to climate, such as green or sustainability-linked bonds. Building a pipeline of bankable energy transition and climate projects could also be useful. Two, stakeholders could work to expand the tax base and align taxation to climate objectives, for instance, through implementing tax collection improvements or eliminating fossil fuel subsidies. The latter could take valuable resources away from cash-constrained public resources and discourage investments in energy-efficient technologies, making it more difficult for cleaner and renewable forms of energy to compete. \u003cspan\u003eFinally, stakeholders could consider restructuring sovereign debt, for example through debt-for-climate and debt-for-nature swaps, implementing climate innovations in sovereign debt instruments such as automatic interest moratoriums in the event of catastrophes, and reducing borrowing costs through measures to reduce country risk and increase sovereign bond liquidity through better-developed repo markets\u003c/span\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eTransformative change is within reach\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe window to stabilize the globe\u0026rsquo;s climate trajectory and limit global temperature increases is closing, so near-term results matter greatly for the future of vulnerable developing countries and the rest of humanity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that climate action and economic development need not be a trade-off but can be mutually reinforcing. While the investment required for climate initiatives is significant, it promises to unlock new revenue streams and export markets for developing countries. These countries can also take a leading role in environmental stewardship. Realizing the estimated potential for increasing domestic and international financing will be challenging and depends on numerous actors and initiatives all \u0026ldquo;doing their part.\u0026rdquo; For example, domestic resource mobilization requires tax reforms, which rely on subnational and local implementation efforts. The achievable leverage ratio assumes a particular mix of instruments and private capital mobilization for each instrument\u0026mdash;all of which may depend on initiatives like MDB reform and fiscal incentives for climate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eAdditional complexities to consider\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThese numbers emphasize the scale of the problem, but additional complexities and underlying dynamics need to be considered.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, the share of public versus private finance is not uniform across sectors and green technologies. In the energy sector, for example, geothermal and hydropower are historically heavily reliant on public finance (68 percent and 97 percent, respectively), whereas only 31 percent of renewable energy investments are currently publicly funded.[[footnote 1]] For other sectors, such as adaption finance, water, land use, and disaster risk mitigation, only 0.1 percent of climate finance has been from private sources. Some sectors in developing countries, notably agriculture, require significant investment to set countries on a path toward green growth. These investments are highly likely to depend on public funding as they often have long payback periods, high upfront costs, or are public goods that may not provide immediate or direct financial returns.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, there is diversity in the sources of private sector financing. These sources range from institutional investors with more than $1 trillion in assets to smaller impact investors, companies, and commercial banks. Each of these sources has different expectations and aspirations for climate-related investments. For example, in terms of return profiles, institutional investors generally focus on the long term due to returns and commercial mandates. In contrast, commercial banks tend to focus on the short to medium term due to commercial goals, and private equity and venture capital investors are often interested in a five- to seven-year investment horizon. These different expectations and aspirations influence the type of climate investments each entity is willing to make.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThird, it is imperative to recognize the dichotomy of mitigation and adaptation in catalyzing green growth. As developing countries look to grow their economies, there is a requirement for them to transition away from an existing dependence on fossil fuels, but also a critical need to ensure that the foundations of future economic growth, especially in agriculture and energy, are built on the principles of both mitigation and adaptation. As things stand, most private climate finance capital is flowing to mitigation. Only 4 percent of private finance mobilized by official development interventions between 2018 and 2020 went to adaptation, compared with 32 percent for climate-related issues.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Uncertainties and additional complexities"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRenewable Energy Investments\u003c/em\u003e, IRENA, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Private investment for climate change adaptation\u0026mdash;difficult to finance or difficult to see the finance?,\u0026rdquo; London School of Economics, March 16, 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"4"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eMobilizing private capital is the crux of the climate finance debate because, in addition to private investors\u0026rsquo; ambitions, it requires efforts from domestic stakeholders and international institutions to create the right investment conditions. Here, we examine how stakeholders can deliver on the three priority actions identified to enable more private FDI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eExpanding the use of finance instruments with higher leverage ratios to catalyze private capital\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eBy employing innovative finance mechanisms such as blended financing and credit enhancement tools, stakeholders could amplify the impact of private capital more effectively than traditional concessional debt and encourage substantial additional investments. According to the OECD, blended concessional finance can cover the political, regulatory, and new technology risks\u0026mdash;among others\u0026mdash;that the private sector cannot, and provide risk mitigation in areas where no or limited market solutions are available for derisking through, for example, insurance or guarantees.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eNot all blended finance instruments are created equal. Guarantees and equity, on average, have the highest leverage ratios, while performance-based instruments have the lowest (exhibit). However, in 2020, guarantees and equity accounted for a much lower share of climate finance in Africa compared to other regions. For example, equity only accounted for about 10 percent of climate investment flows in Africa in 2022, compared with more than 30 percent globally.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit side]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eAs things stand, DFIs and MDBs account for most of the financing in developing countries, especially in Africa, where they contributed 57 percent of financing in 2019 to 2020.[[footnote 3]] However, DFIs' approach to mobilization has been slow to evolve, continuing to rely on traditional approaches and making limited use of structuring techniques and instruments with high mobilization potential. As a result, the instruments used have poor leverage ratios\u0026mdash;0.3 for MDBs and less than 1.0 for DFIs.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eScaling private capital through blended finance hinges on increasing the flow of potential deals and achieving the required risk or return profiles for private investment in those deals. This would require coordinated action across institutions, investment approaches, and stakeholders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThree approaches could accelerate this process. First, including climate mobilization mandates and targets for bilateral, MDB, or DFI capital is crucial, accompanied by strong organizational incentives and the development of supporting capabilities alongside suitable safeguards. Second, stakeholders could scale up and accelerate access to instruments already available through existing institutions. This could be achieved by streamlining application and co-investment processes, boosting project preparation and pipeline development, and supporting collaboration within and across public actors and combinations of blending instruments to manage risks holistically. Finally, stakeholders could grow the impact of guarantee approaches by optimizing products for greater efficiency, expanding the use of proven approaches across more providers and more challenging investment contexts, and developing new global green guarantee platforms, such as a dedicated currency risk facility.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eDomestic efforts to catalyze international private capital\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWhile increasing the amount and effectiveness of capital is critical for developing countries, it is only half the equation. Equally important is creating incentives and market conditions that will attract investors. Many developing countries are linked to significant country risk premiums, which drives up the cost of capital.[[footnote 5]] For example, a consumer price index analysis for solar projects showed that, while investors in developed nations expected returns of 7 percent (Germany) and 9 percent (United States), return expectations for the same level of project risk were much higher in developing nations, with 26 percent, 38 percent, and 52 percent returns expected in Nigeria, Zambia, and Argentina, respectively.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWhile frequently attributed to investor bias and a lack of understanding creating a significant gap between perceived and real country risk, recent research indicates that this difference in risk premiums could, in fact, largely be caused by objectively higher risks and factors such as lower liquidity.[[footnote 6]] International investors also face market-driven challenges, such as foreign exchange risk, but governments could directly address many of these challenges through reforms. This analysis highlights seven common challenges associated with climate finance that may need to be overcome, depending on each country\u0026rsquo;s unique economic and local context:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLimited public-private partnership governance:\u003c/strong\u003e Limited legal frameworks for governing PPPs can increase the likelihood of interference, corruption, instability, and unreliable risk-sharing mechanisms. Potential interventions to combat this include deploying a standardized PPP framework and approach for climate engagements.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInefficient trade environments:\u003c/strong\u003e The market for some renewable energy products is still relatively small, a situation that could be exacerbated by inefficient trade environments that diminish the bankability of climate projects. Potential interventions that may be considered include the introduction of carbon border adjustment mechanisms (CBAMs), which place a tax on high-emission trade (for example, cement produced without deploying carbon capture and storage techniques or other decarbonization measures) and the removal of duty on low-emission products such as green minerals and manufactured goods or zero-emission vehicles. Further, standardizing processes could help simplify them and reduce the time and cost of trading.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eComplex administrative procedures:\u003c/strong\u003e Complicated administrative procedures can hinder the rapid deployment of available capital. To combat this, governments could consider simplifying documentation requirements and permit procedures by implementing transparent systems\u0026mdash;for instance, by establishing a central entity to approve renewable energy projects, reducing the time and cost of business activities.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRestrictive capital controls:\u003c/strong\u003e Capital controls restricting monetary and profit flows out of the country may deter foreign investors as they limit the ease with which investors can repatriate profits or move capital freely. Potential interventions to overcome this challenge could include the introduction of repatriation benefits for companies and new approaches that guarantee to limit capital controls to a fixed percentage of the economy or for a fixed period.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUnclear asset-dispute processes:\u003c/strong\u003e Since climate projects frequently rely on the availability of land, investors may face land-use disputes, with unclear processes as to how to resolve these. Stakeholders could take steps to alleviate this by allocating approved land for climate projects, enabled through an inclusive, centrally managed, digital land registry, and by easing access to risk insurance. Ensuring a central body to oversee climate investment-related issues and resolution could be another potential measure.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eProhibited international arbitration:\u003c/strong\u003e Some developing countries have unfamiliar judiciary systems, which may necessitate international arbitration for external investors in case of conflict. However, not all countries allow this, increasing investor uncertainty. A potential intervention could be the enforcement of country permissions for international arbitration on select matters through international treaties.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAn environment that disincentivizes climate investments:\u003c/strong\u003e A supportive environment can be critical in encouraging climate investment. However, existing policies (including subsidies and tax benefits) that favor high emissions are often historically embedded, while fiscal incentives and subsidies for low-emission and decarbonization projects may be limited. As seen in other countries, lowering interest rates could be considered for climate-related projects, thereby improving climate projects\u0026rsquo; margins and bankability.[[footnote 7]] Further, implementing tax incentives and other benefits for talent and capability building, renewable energy investments, energy efficiency projects, and other climate-related activities could help to attract private capital. Relevant stakeholders could also implement the gradual removal of incentives for high-emission investments and acquisition of high-emission assets, ultimately decommissioning them.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eScaling carbon markets\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn recent years, voluntary carbon markets (VCMs) have emerged as a powerful mechanism to stimulate private sector capital to fund decarbonization projects in developing countries Globally, VCMs grew at about 20 percent per annum from 2016 to reach a value of roughly $2 billion in 2021.[[footnote 8]] However, countries in emerging markets frequently do not fully realize the potential of VCMs as a tool to raise climate finance and meet climate targets. For instance, Africa\u0026rsquo;s carbon credit volumes, with only 25 MtCO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003ee retired in 2022, fall appreciably short of the region\u0026rsquo;s technical potential, estimated to be approximately 2,400 MtCO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003ee by 2030.[[footnote 9]] The retirement value of Africa\u0026rsquo;s carbon credits in 2021 ($123 million) was just 2 percent of the continent\u0026rsquo;s potential 2030 market size if barriers are addressed.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn its \u003cem\u003e2022 Roadmap Report\u003c/em\u003e, the Africa Carbon Markets Initiative (ACMI) identified four actions across the carbon market value chain that could help scale VCMs in Africa and other developing countries:[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSupplying carbon credits:\u003c/strong\u003e The supply of carbon credits requires that project developers be scaled, for instance, through setting up an accelerator that supports high-potential nascent projects and reinforces targeted, on-the-ground technical assistance as well as the development of national enabling ecosystems, including developing fiscal policies that facilitate carbon credit applications. Validation capacity for CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions reductions or removals needs also to be increased as it is currently a key bottleneck that is holding back developing countries\u0026rsquo; carbon markets.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSupporting a more integrated carbon market though intermediation:\u003c/strong\u003e Better integration by coordinating with carbon credit exchanges and committing to common standards could help enhance carbon markets in developing countries. Additionally, introducing financial mechanisms tailored to the emerging market context could help mitigate risks and lower costs. This could involve encouraging financial institutions to value carbon revenue like other revenue streams and adjust risk frameworks to enable lending against carbon revenue, thereby promoting investment in carbon credit projects.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDriving demand:\u003c/strong\u003e Driving demand to increase market size could be encouraged by convening buyers through advanced market commitments, building a supply pool (for example, by launching annual requests for proposals to solicit proposals from African project developers), and facilitating transactions through an auction mechanism.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAdopting a cross-cutting approach:\u003c/strong\u003e Between 2016 and 2022, 95 percent of carbon credits issued in Africa were in agriculture, forestry and land use, and household devices and energy.[[footnote 12]] Stakeholders could investigate piloting new cross-cutting project types and methodologies focused on displacing fossil fuels via distributed renewable energy, coal decommissioning, and savannah grasslands\u0026rsquo; fire management projects. Additionally, diversified financing models for nature-based assets could help scale VCMs. These include models that incorporate ecosystem value-based instruments like sustainable-use fees, payments for ecosystem services, and insurance premium discounts. Compensation-based instruments such as ecotaxes, extractive fees, royalties, and permits could be explored to scale VCMs. Throughout the process, close coordination with global standard-setting organizations such as the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM), the Voluntary Carbon Markets Integrity Initiative (VCMI), and the Science Based Targets Initiative (SBTi) would be beneficial.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Delivering on priority actions to drive private
